column4: Does "64 bit support" mean that a processor is a 64 bit processor?
if that's on the software, it means it's compiled for the amd64 instruction set
I'm asking about the hardware.... I can't install ubuntu 64 so i'm trying to figure out if my processor isnt really 64 bit
what do you have running on the system now?
doesn't windows xp have the capability of telling you what sort of processor you have? something like 'cat /proc/cpuinfo' on linux?
I know which processor i have, http://www.newegg.com/product/product.asp?item=N82E16819116004
according to wikipedia, it looks as if the processor does implement the AMD64 instruction set
are you using an ubuntu live cd for 64bit architecture?
and then you burnt the cd and now it doesn't boot or doesn't boot correctly from the cd?
It dosen't boot correctly from the cd
how far does it get? when it asks if you want to boot from cd, can you edit the entry and delete "splash" and "quiet"?
I found my exact problem on the forums, this is exactly what happens to me, described on the first post: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=491544&highlight=64+intel+amd+ubuntu+install
i'd bet on the kernel configuration on the live cd not supporting something
why would it work on the 32 bit version but not on the 64 bit version?
but what happens if you switch off the splash screen and 'quiet' on the boot options?
i don't know how to do that....
hang on, i'll power up my laptop and tell you exactly what to do...
okay: put the cd in the drive. wait till the screen appears where you can select what you want to do, press F6. delete 'quiet' and 'splash'. press enter
ok i did that and absolutely nothing different happned
then something's going wrong very early in procedings. either you use the 32bit version, or you try gutsy
i you want to stick to 64-bit edgy, you can spend some time researching 'kernel options at boot time', but that will soon get extremely boring
